structured_info.title_cn: 管理车道策略对近期部署协同自适应巡航控制的有效性
structured_info.title_en: The effectiveness of managed lane strategies for the near-term deployment of cooperative adaptive cruise control
structured_info.abstract: Traffic simulation is a cost-effective way to test the deployment of Cooperative Adaptive Cruise Control (CACC) vehicles in a large-scale transportation network. By using a previously developed microscopic simulation testbed, this paper examines the impacts of four managed lane strategies for the near-term deployment of CACC vehicles under mixed traffic conditions. Network-wide performance measures are investigated from the perspectives of mobility, safety, equity, and environmental impacts. In addition, the platoon formation performance of CACC vehicles is evaluated with platoon-orientated measures, such as the percentage of platooned CACC vehicles, average platoon depth, and vehicle-hour-platooned that is proposed in this paper under the imperfect DSRC communication environment. Moreover, managed lane score matrices are developed to incorporate heterogeneous categories of performance measures, aiming to provide a more comprehensive picture for stakeholders. The results show that mixing CACC traffic along with non-CACC traffic across all travel lanes is an acceptable option when the market penetration (MP) is lower than 30% for roadways where a managed lane is absent. Providing CACC with priority access to an existing managed lane, if available, is also a good strategy for improving the overall traffic performance when the MP is lower than 40%. When the MP reaches above 40%, a dedicated lane for CACC vehicles is recommended, as it provides greater opportunity for CACC vehicles to form platoons. The facilitation of homogeneous CACC traffic flow could make further improvements possible in the future.
structured_info.methodology: Microscopic traffic simulation using PTV Vissim, Vissim Component Object Model (COM) interface, and the Vissim DriverModel.DLL application programming interface (VEDM). The simulation framework evaluates four managed lane strategies under mixed traffic conditions.
structured_info.conclusion: For locations without existing managed lane policy, mixing CACC traffic across all travel lanes is an acceptable option when the market penetration rate is below 30%. Mixed managed lane (e.g., HOV + CACC, HOT + CACC) is a versatile option for providing priority lane usage for CACC vehicles, especially in the locations where ML strategies have already been implemented. It is premature to implement CACC lane when market penetration (MP) is below 30%, due to the degradation of the traffic condition on the general purpose lanes. When the mid-range MP (30% to 55%) is reached, CACC lane begins to show its advantages for facilitating CACC clustering and forming homogeneous CACC traffic that is ultimately necessary for the further harness of the benefits of CACC (e.g., higher speed limit and short headway intra-platoon car following).

analysis.Overview: The paper examines the effectiveness of four managed lane strategies for the near-term deployment of Cooperative Adaptive Cruise Control (CACC) vehicles under mixed traffic conditions using microscopic traffic simulation. The study evaluates network-wide performance measures from mobility, safety, equity, and environmental impact perspectives.
Background_and_Motivation: The research addresses the challenge of deploying CACC vehicles in mixed traffic conditions, focusing on the role of managed lane strategies.
The motivation is to derive policy recommendations for the initial introduction of CACC vehicles into mixed traffic, considering safety, technological, and budgetary concerns.
The authors argue that simulation is a cost-effective approach to bridge the gap between prototype testing and large-scale real-world deployment of CACC technology.
The study relates the specific problem of CACC deployment to broader challenges in traffic management and establishes its significance by evaluating various performance measures.
The paper contributes to transportation engineering, specifically in the areas of traffic simulation, managed lane strategies, and connected and automated vehicle technologies.
Conceptual_Framework_and_Innovations: Core concepts include Managed Lane (ML) strategies, Cooperative Adaptive Cruise Control (CACC), and platoon formation.
The logical relationship involves how ML strategies facilitate CACC deployment, which in turn affects platoon formation and overall traffic performance.
Key assumptions include the use of conservative time gaps for CACC vehicles and the incorporation of imperfect DSRC communication.
The paper contributes to the knowledge system by proposing new performance measures (e.g., vehicle-hour-platooned) and developing score matrices for evaluating ML strategies.
Methodology: The core research method is microscopic traffic simulation using PTV Vissim, enhanced with custom CACC behavioral models and V2V communication modules.
The methodology is novel in its integration of local coordination for CACC platooning and its applicability to real-world traffic conditions.
Data sources include INRIX travel time, remote traffic microwave sensor data, and video camera footage, ensuring realistic representation of traffic conditions.
The experimental design is rigorous, with five replications for each combination of strategy and market penetration. Evaluation metrics include mobility, safety, equity, and environmental impact.
The research follows a simulation-based paradigm, common in transportation engineering, to explore hypothetical scenarios and derive policy recommendations.
Results: Key results show that mixing CACC traffic with non-CACC traffic is acceptable for MP < 30%, while dedicated CACC lanes are recommended for MP > 40%.
The results are significant for policy-making in CACC deployment, demonstrating reliable and stable improvements in traffic performance under specific conditions.
Argumentation_and_Logic: The authors structure their argument by first reviewing relevant literature, then detailing their methodology, and finally presenting and discussing results.
Key steps include the calibration of the simulation framework, evaluation of four ML strategies, and development of score matrices.
Strengths include comprehensive performance measures and practical recommendations. Weaknesses may include assumptions about CACC behavior and communication reliability.
Strengths_and_Limitations: Strengths include the development of new performance measures and a robust simulation framework.
Limitations include assumptions about CACC vehicle behavior and the focus on a specific roadway segment.
The choice of simulation-based methodology constrains conclusions to hypothetical scenarios, requiring further validation in real-world settings.
Academic_Discourse_and_Rhetoric: The paper contributes to ongoing discourse on CACC deployment and managed lane strategies.
Terminology includes technical terms like 'vehicle-hour-platooned' and 'managed lane score matrices.' The tone is analytical and policy-oriented.
The authors build authority through extensive citations of prior work and practical recommendations for stakeholders.
Conclusions_and_Implications: Main conclusions highlight the suitability of different ML strategies based on market penetration rates.
Future research should explore optimization of CACC-ML operations and interactions between CAVs and human-driven vehicles.
